awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation. Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe and can be used to test fundamental physics. The High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) observatory, located on the slopes of the Sierra Negra in Mexico, is a ground-based facility designed with unique capabilities to observe very high energy gamma-rays. This award supports scientists at the University of Maryland College Park in their leadership roles in the operation of the observatory and in the scientific analysis of the HAWC data. The group will continue activities to optimize the sensitivity of the observatory and pursue scientific research on transient gamma-ray sources and newly discovered very high energy sources. This award will allow the group to continue and expand their outreach efforts, which include outreach to the Hispanic-American community with bi-lingual products related to HAWC. 

With its large instantaneous field of view and continuous operations HAWC surveys two-thirds of the sky every day.  The University of Maryland group will continue their study of transient sources with HAWC as part of a multi-messenger and multi-wavelength campaign.  They will also continue their work producing maps and conducting surveys to reveal new high energy gamma-ray sources.  In addition, they will continue to lead the effort to exploit the novel water Cherenkov detection technique to improve the sensitivity of HAWC.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

This is the Project Outcomes report for the University of Maryland (UMD) Particle Astrophysics with HAWC grant. The High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) Gamma-ray Observatory (See Figure 1.) is a wide field of view, continuously operating TeV gamma-ray telescope that is exploring the origin of cosmic rays, studying the acceleration of particles in extreme physical environments, and searching for new physics at the TeV-PeV scale. The main HAWC 300 tank detector array was completed on March 20, 2015 with the 350 smaller tank outrigger array being completed in 2018. The UMD group's science focus has been on development of reconstruction tools, point source and extended source analysis, un-triggered gamma ray bursts, and multi-messenger astrophysics. We also have had a major role in HAWC project management. 

HAWC is a wide-field instrument that surveys more than half the sky every day, making it an ideal instrument to discover new sources of TeV gamma rays both in the galaxy and out. The UMD group has played a key role in the development of the newest reconstruction reprocessing pass  (Pass 5) for all of the HAWC data.  We were responsible new algorithm developments leading to higher sensitivity at both low and high energies. The UMD group has been responsible for fine tuning the Pass 5 reconstruction algorithm to improve our pointing and sensitivity at large zenith angles. In Figure 2 the left plot shows the improvement of the “Q” factor (signal over sqrt of background) between the previous reconstruction, Pass 4, and Pass 5. The improvement is most significant for large events and large zenith angles. The right plot shows the improvement in angular resolution again showing a large improvement for large events and large zenith angles. 

Figure 3 shows the HAWC all-sky map using Pass 5, revealing emission all along the Galactic plane, as well as the blazars Mrk 421 and Mrk 501, and, for the first time in HAWC, the radio galaxy M87, which is now seen at 6σ. The data shown are from 2321 days of HAWC operation. This represents the one of the deepest wide-field survey of the northern sky at TeV energies, with ∼100 sources above 5σ detected. This is 40 more than in the 1523-day data set published in the 3HWC catalog using Pass 4 reconstruction. With this better reconstruction and higher sensitivity, the challenge becomes disentangling point sources, extended sources, and diffuse background in order to do more science: make an improved measurement of the truly diffuse emission, resolve previously confused sources, and extract physics from these sources by better correlating their morphology with structures seen in other wavelengths (radio through gamma rays) and constrain models of emission with improved spectral measurements.

In addition, we are working on incorporating the outriggers in our reconstruction which will be Pass 6. Also we have had a lead role in a number of HAWC publications, as well as issuing and responding to real time alerts. As of December 2023 we have analyzed 2890 days of HAWC data with our Pass 5 analysis which has given us increased sensitivity at lower energies, better angular resolution, a wider field of view, and better gamma/hadron separation. This allowed us to discover a number of new sources including a new micro-quasar emitting above 25 TeV and as described below TeV gamma rays from the Sun.

One of the more interesting results in the last year was the first detection of a TeV gamma-ray flux from the solar disk. The Sun shadows cosmic rays that are coming from the Sun’s direction. We see a gamma ray excess in the shadow. This is likely the result of cosmic rays mirroring off the Sun’s magnetic field and interaction in the corona on the way back out. In Figure 4 one can see the shadow subtracted flux and the gamma ray excess. In Figure 5 we show that the gamma flux is dependent on the solar cycle as has been seen at GeV energies and that the flux we measure approaches the theoretical maximum from Cosmic ray interactions, but orders of magnitude above the predicted interactions in the limb of the Sun.

HAWC is one of the most visible science projects in Mexico. We have taken advantage of this by creating an extensive public outreach program in both English and Spanish in the US and Mexico. We have actively engage students from high school to graduate school from both the US and Mexico in the construction, analysis and operation of the HAWC detector and are working to attract under-represented groups to study in the field. We have sponsored summer students from HBCU’s to do summer research at Maryland. Our students have gone on to give presentations at national physics meetings are planning on attending graduate school in Physics.
